Brief Summary
-----------------
Severe diabetes and depression are associated with severe consequences like mortality. This association is believed to be due to an increase in physical morbidity when depression is present, such as cardiac disease, poor adherence to treatment, hospital stays, and renal failure. All participants will be interviewed by research professionals and screened for clinical depression and diabetes. During the Screening and Baseline phase, subjects will undergo a screening process, including medical evaluation, psychiatric assessment, and assessment for suicidal risk. Participants who meet the study
criteria will be randomized to participate in the open-label treatment phase or the double-blind treatment phase.
During the open-label treatment phase, subjects will receive a fixed dose of LY240031, administered once daily, regardless of BPAD symptoms. Treatment will be administered for a total of 8 weeks, after which subjects will be assessed for safety and tolerability.
During the double-blind treatment phase, subjects will be randomly assigned to either the LY240031 or Placebo Group. Following the randomization, they will receive treatment with LY240031 or Placebo once daily for a total of 8 weeks. Both groups will receive double-blind treatment for 8 weeks. After 8 weeks, subjects will be assessed for safety and tolerability.

Abstract:
This study investigated the effects of the new passive heating device Vessyl Heat Wave®, in comparison to a control intervention, on muscle temperature during acute inactivity (4 hours) in healthy individuals. Thirty volunteers (15 males and 15 females) were recruited. The volunteers were randomly divided into 2 groups: passive heating (PH) and control group (CG). The PH group used the heating device during inactivity. The CG consisted of static stretching on quadriceps, hamstrings, and gluteal muscles, followed by 5‐minutes of lying on a bed in a room with a constant temperature of 22±2℃. Before and after the intervention, a thermal sensitivity test, heart rate (HR) and peripheral peripheral skin temperature (Tsk) were measured in both groups. Muscle temperature was measured in both legs and thighs of lower limbs as the main outcome variable. Statistical analysis was conducted using the Bonferroni post‐hoc or Student t‐test. The results showed that Tsk value was higher in the PH group (p<0.05). The heart rate decreased after the intervention in the PH group compared to before the intervention (p<0.05). In the CG, muscle temperature was not significantly different compared to before the intervention (p>0.05). Vessyl Heat Wave® may increase blood circulation, improving overall blood microcirculation during bedrest (cooling). As a result, the heart rate decreases due to a decrease in body temperature. Therefore, the PH group is recommended for nursing care environments to maintain the temperature of bedridden patients.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: The optimal mode of treatment of early rheumatoid arthritis is not yet entirely clear.AIMS: To identify factors affecting outcome in patients with early rheumatoid arthritis after treatment with methotrexate and sulfasalazine.METHODS: We examined data obtained from a randomized clinical trial comparing methotrexate and sulfasalazine with placebo given in addition to antirheumatic treatment of the patients' choice in patients with early rheumatoid arthritis. One hundred and ninety four subjects with rheumatoid arthritis with symptom duration between 12 and 24 months were randomized to treatment with sulfasalazine and methotrexate (n = 110), or with placebo (n = 84). The main outcome measure was functional disability, measured by Health Assessment Questionnaire. We analysed data in a multivariable regression model with disability as the outcome after 1 and 2 years.RESULTS: Of the patients, 20% were on methotrexate monotherapy, 8% on sulfasalazine monotherapy, and 26% on both. In the multivariable model we included disease activity, and the following variables: baseline age, female gender, high educational level, and smoking. For all patients we found that education, disease activity, and female gender were independent predictors of disability at 12 months, with female gender having the greatest detrimental effect (OR = 4.2 (1.5, 12.0)). After 24 months we found that education, disease activity and smoking still showed independent prognostic value, but female gender no longer did.CONCLUSION: We conclude that female gender is a strong predictor of functional disability at 12 months, while in the longer term, education, disease activity, and smoking are important determinants of disease evolution. 2004 The Author(s).

Abstract:
Aim of the study: This study aims to assess the effect of dietary supplementation with a plant‐derived supplementary foodstuff on oxidative stress and blood pressure in patients with hypertension and high blood sugar levels. Study method: A prospective, randomized, placebo‐controlled, parallel‐group, double‐blind trial was undertaken on 160 subjects aged 50‐70 years diagnosed with essential hypertension combined with impaired fasting glucose (IFG) or impaired glucose tolerance. The study population was divided into two groups: active (n‐80), which received 60 mg of dietary supplements (plant‐derived glycyrrhizic acid, hesperidin, catechin, and carnosic acid) twice daily for 3 months and placebo group (n‐80) who received placebos twice daily. Blood pressure measurements, routine laboratory assessment, and determination of carbohydrate‐induced glucose metabolism were done at baseline and after 3 months of intervention. Results: It is well known that chronic inflammation is related to cardiovascular diseases (CVDs). Hesperetin, catechin, and carnosic inhibit the production of pro‐inflammatory cytokines and ROS (reactive oxygen species) activity. The activity of α‐amylase and α‐glucosidase, which affect carbohydrate metabolism in the body, were reduced in the treatment group. A significant increase in the antioxidant enzyme activity, the levels of nitric oxide ( NO), and insulin sensitivity index is reported. In conclusion, it is shown that the results of this study confirmed the positive effect of the plant‐derived supplementary foodstuff on the pathophysiology of chronic inflammation and oxidative stress in diabetic patients after 90 days of oral administration. 2015, NSC‐1

Abstract:
Objective: The aim of this study is to compare treatment outcome between simple release and early tendon slide procedure in acute carpal tunnel syndrome. Methods: This is a case‐control study with total 45 cases of carpal tunnel syndrome. Cases were divided into two groups. Group 1 included 15 cases treated by simple surgery and group 2 included 30 cases treated by the early tendon slide procedure at the acute stage of carpal tunnel syndrome. Outcomes of both groups were compared to evaluate the efficacy of these procedures. Result: In both groups, patients showed improvement after surgical release. However, in group 2, the post‐operative improvement was significantly better in the early tendon slide procedure than that in group 1. Conclusion: The early tendon slide procedure is better when indicated for acute carpal tunnel syndrome.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to investigate the use of lung ultrasound (LUS) during the perioperative period in shoulder arthroscopic surgery.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Intraoperative fluid management in shoulder arthroscopic surgery is essential to achieve the balance between effective hemodynamics and the avoidance of fluid overload. Clinical judgment alone is insufficient. LUS, as a novel, non-invasive, and easily detectable tool, has the potential to assist clinicians in understanding and predicting changes in hemodynamic status during and after surgery. This research was intended to investigate the efficacy of lung ultrasound in improving fluid management and preventing pulmonary complications in shoulder arthroscopic surgery, which has been rarely done previously. A total of 60 patients, including 24 in the experimental group and 36 in the control group from March 2022 to October 2022 will be randomly assigned to these two groups. The experimental group will undergo LUS-based intraoperative fluid management, whereas the control group will receive routine care. The outcome parameters will be measured and recorded at several time points in both groups. The two groups will be compared statistically, and the effectiveness of the experimental group's approach will be evaluated in terms of intraoperative fluid management, postoperative pulmonary complications, hemodynamics, and patient comfort.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a highly prevalent, complex, and costly mental health disorder affecting up to 15% of young adults in the United States. Prevention and treatment programs play a crucial role in reducing the burden of AUD. However, traditional outpatient treatment programs have been found to be insufficient in addressing AUD in adolescents and young adults (AYAs) due to low adherence. This randomized controlled trial will examine the effectiveness of a brief web-based intervention for the prevention and treatment of AUD in this at-risk population. The online intervention combines virtual reality (VR) immersive exposure therapy with cognitive behavioral therapy and motivational interviewing. It includes personalized feedback, tracking progress, and interactive activities designed to motivate youth. The research team will enroll up to 116 AYAs with sub-clinical or moderate-to-severe AUD. Data on alcohol use, alcohol-related problems, and quality of life will be collected at screening, baseline, and post-treatment at two and four months. The study aims to evaluate the intervention's effectiveness in reducing alcohol use, alcohol-related problems, and improving quality of life.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The use of ketamine to treat anxiety in schizophrenia is a relatively new area. Many patients with schizophrenia and psychosis experience significant distress from anxiety symptoms, with many patients unable to benefit from a standard SSRI treatment. Ketamine has been studied in acute treatment of anxiety in this patient population, but we need to better understand whether such benefits are sustained. Therefore, we plan to examine the effects of low-dose (0.2 mg/kg) weekly ketamine treatment in patients suffering with schizophrenia and anxiety.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Psychosis and/or bipolar disorder is frequently accompanied by anxiety, which is associated with functional impairment and poor outcomes. Anxiety has been consistently shown to be an enduring feature of schizophrenia, with an incidence of 30% in early phases of psychosis (Strawn et al., 2017). In fact, anxiety is often a better predictor of functional outcomes than psychotic symptoms such as hallucinations and positive delusions (Gelkopf, Leweke, & Zohar, 2013). Additionally, patients with anxiety and poor functioning are also at an increased risk for the development of psychosis and other severe mental illness later in life (Goodman et al., 2011). Importantly, many anxiety symptoms have been shown to persist in psychosis despite normalization of delusions and hallucinations after treatment with antipsychotic medications (Perry et al., 2015). Further, treatment with antipsychotics can increase anxiety and the rate of dropouts in psychotic patients, suggesting a need for complimentary approaches (Perry et al., 2015). Therefore, new strategies to treat anxiety in patients with schizophrenia are urgently needed. Ketamine has emerged as a novel and potentially promising treatment for anxiety, as there is a growing body of literature in support of its efficacy and safety in this population of patients (Mortensen & Farahbakhsh, 2018). Although the use of ketamine as a therapeutic agent for major depressive disorder is well documented (Berman et al., 2000), multiple studies have also shown that a single intr

Treatment-as-usual approach to moderate-to-severe alcohol use disorders was previously based on 3 levels of treatment: (a) primary care, (b) partial hospitalisation (residential or non-residential) and (c) intensive outpatient. This study aims to determine if treatment-as-usual approach for the treatment of alcohol use disorders in Canada, that has been proven effective for moderate-to-severe alcohol use disorders, will be as effective when provided in a virtual environment.The primary object of this pragmatic cohort study will therefore be to: (a) Estimate the effectiveness of the Intensive Virtual Treatment for alcohol use disorders. (b) Identify predictive factors regarding individual treatment response and (c) Determine whether virtual treatment is equally effective in different types of participants.For the first objective, it is proposed to compare the number of consecutive days of alcohol abstinence over the 28-day period prior to the trial and at 1-year after the trial. For the second objective, it is proposed to compare different clinical characteristics at the beginning of the trial and at the end with the number of consecutive days of abstinence before and after the trial.

What is the study measuring?
=================
Primary outcome measures
=================
Days of alcohol abstinence: primary outcome will be measured by the percentage of number of consecutive days with 100% abstinence for the 28 days leading up to the first virtual group session (Day 1) and repeated at the end of the 28 days following the last virtual group session (Week 4).

Secondary outcome measures
=================
1. The number of days with partial abstinence or continuous partial abstinence measured from electronic devices (smartwatches).
2. A score less than or equal to 2 on the Alcohol Withdrawal Scale at the beginning,

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Despite the availability of advanced wound dressings, patients who suffer from recurrent painful wounds remain a significant challenge for the medical care system, especially with the aging population and the increase in diabetes and other chronic inflammatory diseases. To alleviate pain and improve healing in non-healing wounds such as diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) and venous ulcers (VU), medical professionals often need to resort to topically applied, invasive and time-consuming treatments. In this study we develop a safe, non-invasive method to deliver an advanced and innovative therapeutic system directly within the wound tissue. Hereby our goal is to reduce wound related pain and to enable enhanced wound healing, by precisely controlled delivery of pharmaceutical molecules into the wound tissue of diabetic wounds. This study will evaluate the clinical efficacy of a wound healing system based on an active substance, nanocapsulations and electrostimulation on diabetic wounds. To test the effects, the study will compare patient groups treated with the advanced wound dressing to placebo and conventional dressings. The purpose of this study is to demonstrate that wounds heal faster, and that the wound associated pain is reduced, when compared to placebo and conventional dressings. The primary study objective is therefore, to compare the time to healing of diabetic wounds treated with the wound healing system (WH-sys) in relation to conventional wound dressings. The secondary study objective is to examine any difference in wound related pain of diabetic wounds treated with the WH-sys in relation to conventional wound dressings.

Official Title
-----------------
A Phase 2, Multi-center, Prospective, Blinded, Randomized, Crossover Study, Comparing the Time to Healing of Non-healing Diabetic Wounds Treated With and Without Electrostimulation of Nanocapsules

Lung transplantation is an aggressive, lifelong treatment of end-stage lung disease. Although the initial and medium term survival has improved considerably over the last few decades, some patients fail to meet expectations, with 1-minute survival at 1, 5 and 10 years estimated at 63%, 45% and 36% respectively. Despite several studies, the cause of late chronic graft lung disease (CLGD) remains unknown.There is a growing body of evidence to suggest that early changes at the time of transplant predict late CLGD in adult lung transplantation. However, pediatric transplant recipients are often categorized with adult transplant recipients in studies, and the impact of differences in underlying lung disease, and the potential for immunologic effects has yet to be defined in the pediatric population. This registry will determine the association of early and late-phase outcome with early interventions in children receiving lung transplants.This project will utilize the existing data from pediatric lung transplantation at Primary Children's Hospital. This information is housed in the Sibling Data Registry which is approved by the UCSD Data and Safety Board. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to compare two commonly used protocols for post-operative pain management after gynecologic laparoscopic surgery, both of which use acetaminophen and NSAIDS, with the goal of assessing the effectiveness and side effects of each.

Detailed Description
-----------------
After patients have general anesthesia for a routine gynecologic laparoscopic procedure, they will be divided into two groups. In one group, patients will receive acetaminophen (Tylenol) and prescription-strength ibuprofen (Motrin) after completion of surgery. In the second group, patients will receive acetaminophen (Tylenol) and celecoxib (Celebrex) after completion of surgery. Pain monitoring and recording will be performed at 2, 6, and 12 hours after surgery. The pain levels and side effects of each group will be compared to determine whether one group has a lower pain level and/or lower incidence of side effects.

Official Title
-----------------
A Comparative Study of Two Post-operative Pain Management Protocols for Gynecologic Laparoscopic Surgeries

1. Introduction
Neuroblastoma is a cancer that affects infants and children, and it is the most common extracranial solid tumor in childhood. It develops from immature cells in the sympathetic nervous system, which is part of the autonomic nervous system . Neuroblastoma can occur anywhere in the body, but it is most commonly found in the adrenal glands, neck, chest, and spine . Patients with neuroblastoma are typically diagnosed at a young age, with most cases occurring before the age of 5.
The standard treatment for patients with neuroblastoma consists of chemotherapy, surgery, and radiation therapy. The goal of treatment is to shrink the tumor and kill the cancer cells.
The National Cancer Institute has classified neuroblastoma into different stages depending on the severity of the disease and the likelihood of achieving a complete response to treatment. This classification system is based on several factors, including the location of the tumor, the age of the patient, and the extent of the tumor.
High-risk patients have a poor prognosis and are at a higher risk of relapse after initial treatment. This group of patients requires more aggressive treatment, such as intensive chemotherapy, stem cell transplants, radiation therapy, or other targeted therapy . Despite advances in treatment, the overall survival rate for patients with high-risk neuroblastoma is still low, highlighting the need for more effective therapies .
Naxitamab is a monoclonal antibody (mAb) that targets the disialoganglioside (GD2) antigen, which is expressed on the surface of neuroblastoma cells. It has been shown to have antitumor activity in vitro and in vivo, inducing antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) and complement-dependent cytotoxicity (CDC) against neuroblastoma cells . GM-CSF, or granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor, is a protein that stimulates the growth and differentiation of immune cells, such as neutrophils and macrophages, which can also have antitumor activity. The study has a single group assignment. It means that all the participants in the study will receive the same intervention or treatment. Could you briefly describe the intervention or treatment?

The motor-cable-driven system intervention will use a custom-built robotic device to provide wrist and forearm rehabilitation to the affected arm of the stroke patients. The device consists of a motor-cable-driven mechanism mounted on a table. The robot will move the patient's arm through a series of joint angles while the patient moves their hand. The standard rehabilitation therapy arm will follow the recommended therapies in the national guidelines. This includes range-of-motion exercises, strength training, and activities of daily living. What do you think?
In the control group, participants will receive standard rehabilitation therapy, which may include physical therapy, occupational therapy, and/or speech therapy.

Participants in both the experimental and control groups will undergo an initial assessment to assess baseline abilities. The assessment will involve a physical examination of the affected arm and forearm, including evaluation of grip strength, motor and sensory testing, and functional abilities. This will help to objectively measure the effectiveness of the motor-cable-driven system and standard rehabilitation therapy in promoting wrist and forearm recovery. 

Based on the results of the clinical trial, the system will be validated for use in the real world. The study will enroll approximately 30 subjects with moderate to severe upper extremity weakness following stroke. Participants will be required to provide informed consent before enrolling in the study. 

During the course of the study, participants will undergo a comprehensive evaluation at enrollment and after the intervention period, including measures of grip strength, motor and sensory testing, and functional abilities. The results will be analyzed and compared between the two groups to determine the effectiveness of the intervention. 

The findings of this study will contribute to the development of evidence-based guidelines for wrist and forearm rehabilitation, improving outcomes and quality of life for stroke survivors.

groundtruth: Understood. Now, let's move on to the criteria for participant inclusion and exclusion. Can you provide those details?

Thank you for the comprehensive criteria. Now, let's proceed to designing the study arms based on the information provided. We have two participant groups/arms to consider. The first one is primary surgical tumor resection with anastomosis or only tumor resection without anastomosis. The intervention/treatment for this arm is primary tumor resection. This arm is crucial as it represents the standard approach for treating obstructive left colon cancer. It allows for the comparison between patients undergoing primary surgical tumor resection with a primary colorectal anastomosis or without an anastomosis (Hartmann's procedure). This comparison will help determine the optimal surgical approach for these patients in terms of outcomes such as stoma rate, morbidity, mortality, and quality of life. What are your thoughts on this arm?

That's a valid point. We can modify the intervention/treatment description to specify primary surgical tumor resection with a primary colorectal anastomosis, associated with or without a diverting loop ileostomy. This modification will allow us to analyze the impact of diverting loop ileostomy on stoma rate and quality of life. Thank you for your input! Now, let's move on to the second participant group/arm. This arm involves endoscopic stent positioning. The intervention/treatment is staged resection after endoscopic stenting with Self-expandable Metallic Stent (SEMS). This arm is necessary to evaluate the efficacy and safety of endoscopic stenting as a bridge to surgery for patients with obstructive left colon cancer. By comparing this approach with primary surgical tumor resection, we can assess the outcomes and benefits of each strategy, such as stoma rate, morbidity, mortality, and timing of chemotherapy initiation. This comparison will provide valuable information for clinicians in selecting the most appropriate treatment option for these patients. What are your thoughts on this arm?

Absolutely. The comparison of outcomes between these two arms will contribute significantly to the understanding of the benefits and risks associated with each approach. Now that we have discussed both arms, here are the full study arms for the clinical trial:

   Intervention/Treatment: Procedure: primary tumor resection

2. Participant Group/Arm: Endoscopic stent positioning
   Intervention/Treatment: Staged resection after endoscopic stenting with Self-expandable Metallic Stent (SEMS)

These study arms will enable researchers to compare different treatment approaches for obstructive left colon cancer and provide valuable insights into optimal management strategies.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the safety and efficacy of AKL-T04 in patients with relapsed or refractory leukemia or lymphoma and to better understand the effect of this treatment on patients' leukemia or lymphoma. In each study, researchers will find the highest tolerable dose of AKL-T04 in people who have been treated before or whose blood disease has come back (relapsed). In the relapsed study, a total of 54 patients will be enrolled; in the relapsed/refractory study, the 18 patients will be enrolled. T04 will be given by intravenous (IV) infusion (an injection through a thin flexible tube into a vein) at doses ranging from 0.3 to 3 milligrams (mg) per kilogram (kg) of body weight per hour for a maximum of 12 continuous hours for six consecutive days or seven continuous hours per day for six consecutive days. On Day 7, patients who have completed AKL-T04 are followed until the end of the treatment phase of the study. Patients who respond positively to AKL-T04 and who are not experiencing any significant side effects may continue to a second round of T04.

Abstract:
Objectives: To assess the value of early sepsis‐related organ failure assessment (SOFA) score (the primary outcome) and new score predicting septic shock (SAPS III score, the secondary outcome) (as well as procalcitonin (PCT), the exploratory outcome) as predictors of mortality over the entire ICU stay in septic patients. Methods: Data from over 2000 patients admitted to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) with sepsis were analysed. Using a retrospective cohort analysis, the impact of the new SOFA score was studied in comparison with the standard SOFA score and the SAPS III score. Afterwards, patients were randomly divided into three strata of high, medium and low severity of illness (with mortality rate > 30%, 20‐30% and 0‐10%, respectively) on the first day for the development of mortality predictive scores based on admission data which were combined with 4‐h lactate measurement. Results: Patients with high, medium and low predicted mortality had a mortality rate of 68.29% vs. 25% vs. 0%, with a respective mortality risk ratio of 1‐severity score of 2.56 (95% confidence interval (CI): 1.39 to 4.71). 4‐h lactate measurement predicted mortality independently of severity of illness, adding prognostic information to the severity score (p < 0.0001). Combined sepsis‐related organ failure assessment (SOFA) score, SAPS III score and lactate value predicted mortality in a more accurate way than admission‐only admission scores. Conclusion: A combined model based on sepsis‐related organ failure assessment (SOFA) score, SAPS III score and 4‐h lactate measurement is more accurate in predicting mortality over the entire ICU stay than admission‐only scores. Abstract:
Background: Primary dysmenorrhea is a common gynecological condition characterized by recurrent, painful menstrual cramps. Management of this condition is usually based on nonsteroidal anti‐inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and hormonal treatment, but there is a growing demand for non‐pharmacological alternatives. Objective: To compare the effectiveness of young coconut water, dark chocolate bar, and Ibuprofen in reducing the intensity of primary dysmenorrhea. Methods: A prospective, randomized, open‐label study was conducted in 30 female undergraduate students aged between 17 and 24 years who were diagnosed with primary dysmenorrhea. The patients were divided into three groups: Group 1 received young coconut water, Group 2 received a dark chocolate bar, and Group 3 received Ibuprofen. The primary outcome was the intensity of menstrual pain, measured using a visual analog scale (VAS) scored from 0 to 10, with 0 being no pain and 10 being the most severe pain imaginable. The differences between the groups' VAS scores were compared using a multivariate covariance analysis adjusted for age, study group, and menstrual cycle phase. Results: There was no significant difference in the menstrual pain intensity between Group 1 and Group 2, but a significant difference was found between Group 2 and Group 3. Conclusion: This study indicates that the effectiveness of Ibuprofen in managing primary dysmenorrhea is superior to that of young coconut water and dark chocolate bar.

Study
=================

Brief Summary
-----------------
The trial is a Phase II, non-randomized, multi-cohort study testing molecularly-based therapeutic combinations in resectable colorectal cancer. The eligibility criteria include stage III or IV CRC, pMMR/MSS status, and at least one of the following: HER2 overexpression/amplification, proof-read domain pathogenic mutation of POLE/D1 associated with ultra-mutated status, RAS and BRAF wild type status, or PRESSING negative status. Prior therapy is allowed as long as it was discontinued at least 12 weeks before trial treatment initiation and there is no clinical or radiological evidence of disease progression or symptomatic residual disease from the prior therapy. Trial treatment will follow standard clinical recommendations for the target therapies based on the patient's molecular profile and stage of disease. The interventions/treatments in each cohort are specific to the subgroups, but all interventions/treatments will be administered on an outpatient basis. Following tumor resection, patients will complete follow-up assessments at 8 weeks, 12 weeks, 18 weeks, and then every 3 months for 2 years. The endpoints include tumor response rate, progression-free survival, overall survival, and safety and tolerability. The study is not intended to replace existing therapies, but rather to provide a novel, personalized approach to treatment that may benefit patients with resectable colorectal cancer.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Cohort 1: This cohort will target patients with pMMR/MSS status and HER2 overexpression/amplification. The intervention/treatment for this cohort is trastuzumab deruxtecan. Abstract:
Objective: Osteoporosis is a common clinical problem, affecting up to 20% of the population. It causes one in three hip fractures and one in five vertebral fractures, with significant morbidity and mortality. Although current therapies are effective in many cases, they have important limitations related to side effects, cost and lack of effect in certain patients (e.g. those with predominantly vertebral fractures or those with multiple vertebral fractures despite therapy). It is therefore imperative that new treatments are found, and in particular, an agent that is affordable. MAPK pathway inhibitors have already yielded beneficial effects for the treatment of cancers and may also be beneficial for osteoporosis. MAPK pathway kinase inhibition also produces loss of bone mass. This could potentially lead to adverse effects on bone formation, resulting in a negative effect on bone health. However, the loss of bone mass is not necessarily related to loss of bone quantity, density or fracture risk (i.e. secondary hyperparathyroidism), and in some cases, it may reduce bone resorption without reducing bone density (osteomalacia). Such therapeutic strategies appear to be preferable for individuals who are at risk of severe fractures but have normal or near‐normal bone mass, bone mass density, fracture risk or overall bone health. The aim of the current study is to determine if sotorasib reduces bone resorption in healthy males, and if a higher dose results in superior efficacy. Methods This will be a phase 1b, randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled, 38‐day study (with 35‐day follow‐up) of sotorasib in healthy male subjects, 18 to 55 years of age. -----------------

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Patients with a history of TIA or stroke are at a high risk of the reoccurrence of stroke and TIA. In patients with prior TIA or stroke, anticoagulants and aspirin are often prescribed to prevent stroke recurrence. However, anticoagulants increase the risk of haemorrhagic complications in the brain. Aspirin treatment is associated with dyspepsia, ulcer and gastrointestinal bleeding. Therefore, aspirin monotherapy is not recommended in Asian patients with atrial fibrillation and history of stroke, while anticoagulant treatment is contraindicated in high-risk situations. This study will verify whether the safety and feasibility of using Chinese herbal medicine for prevention of stroke recurrence in these patients. Previous studies have shown that Chinese herbal medicine with anti-platelet effect could increase blood flow to the brain and decrease the risk of stroke by increasing the blood pressure in the brain. Chinese herbal medicines such as Danshen and Tianqingkang were shown to reduce the thickness of the capillary in the brain and improve platelet function. In this study, we will evaluate the effects of Chinese medicine on the safety and feasibility of using Chinese medicine in the prevention of stroke recurrence in patients with prior TIA or stroke who are currently taking anticoagulants. The safety, side-effects, quality of life, and feasibilities of stroke prevention and taking Chinese medicines will be investigated. The blood pressure in the carotid arteries of all patients (high-risk group) will be measured with carotid Doppler ultrasound before and after Chinese medicine use to measure arterial blood flow.

Abstract
=================

Background
-----------------
Breast cancer is a major health issue. Recently, numerous observational studies have shown that higher dietary intake, serum levels, and use of vitamin D supplements reduce breast cancer risk by 30-50%. The underlying molecular mechanisms, however, have not been fully elucidated. The objective of the study is to determine whether vitamin D alone or combined with a dietary intervention is able to reduce risk factors associated with breast cancer. Methods/Design
-----------------
An intervention RCT is conducted to examine the combined effect of vitamin D and dietary modifications on molecular changes in breast cancer initiation processes. A 1-year intervention with two cohorts takes place, consisting of four groups (Group 1: 1000 IU/day of vitamin D; group 2: dietary intervention and a placebo for vitamin D; group 3: 1000 IU/day of vitamin D3 and a dietary intervention; and group 4: placebo for both). Blood is drawn at baseline (month 0), and in all subjects every three months in years 2 and 3, and at 54 months post-randomization. Breast cancer risk factors will be assessed in all subjects every three months of the intervention as well as one year post-intervention.

Objective
-----------------
The objectives of the study are 1) to determine the changes in gene transcripts 2) to identify novel molecular markers for breast cancer risk 3) to investigate the effect of vitamin D supplementation and dietary intervention on breast cancer risk factors in combination with gene transcripts changes and 4) to determine the changes at a metabolomic level for those who consume the recommended food groups to assess the diet-gene interaction on breast cancer

MethodologyA two-armed parallel-controlled superiority trial of patients having a total knee arthroplasty (TKA) or total hip replacement (THR) was conducted.PatientsPatients will be identified after their knee replacements from three elective surgical lists. The investigators, orthopaedic surgeons, nurses, research nurses will be blind to the group assignment. Measurement outcomesThere are three main components used to measure outcomes (i) the costs associated with length of hospital stay from admission to discharge, (ii) physical therapy costs between randomisation to one day and one week after randomisation, and (iii) the patient’s health status and functional recovery using the physical function domain from the 36-Item Short-Form Health Survey (SF-36) and the Modified Harris Hip Score scale (mHHS) for the THR group; Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS) and Knee Society Score (KSS) for the TKA group, and Health-Related Quality of Life - EQ-5D. Assessments of demographics, co-morbidity and surgical characteristics and data on length of hospital stay will be obtained once for each subject during the screening visit. Two raters also evaluated static equilibrium and gait pattern in a blinded fashion using an online video analysis program. Participants who were not diagnosed with cerebellar disorders prior to participation in our study were included in the control group. These individuals underwent a baseline evaluation at our facility but did not use the study drug and therefore, did not receive BoNT‐injections. RESULTS: Thirty‐seven patients with CA were included in the study. The mean age was (63.7 ± 8.7) years. There were no significant differences in baseline characteristics such as age and sex. (2) Statistically significant differences were not noted between Dynamic Movement Syndrome Rating Scale (DMSRS) and the Tinetti Gait item among the 3 BoNT‐injection types. Excellent. Now that we have all the necessary information, let's design the study arms. Based on the details you provided, I suggest the following arms:

1. Experimental: real-rTMS
Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes individuals at risk for Alzheimer's disease who will undergo real repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) sessions.
Intervention/Treatment: The intervention involves 4 daily 25-minute high-frequency rTMS sessions over one week using a 70-mm figure-eight coil at 20Hz. Target localization will be performed with a stereotaxic neuronavigation system.
Reasoning: This arm is essential to test the efficacy of non-invasive stimulation techniques, specifically real rTMS, in modulating the default mode network (DMN) in individuals at risk for Alzheimer's disease. By targeting this specific population with a known genetic risk factor for AD, the study aims to assess the potential benefits of this intervention in early stages of the disease.

2. Sham Comparator: sham-rTMS
Participant Group/Arm: This arm serves as the control group in the study.
Intervention/Treatment: Participants in this arm will undergo 4 daily 25-minute sham-rTMS sessions over one week, where the sham condition will mimic the real rTMS protocol but with a sham coil.
Reasoning: The inclusion of a sham comparator arm is crucial to establish the efficacy of the real rTMS intervention. By comparing the outcomes of the experimental arm with the control arm, researchers can determine whether the observed effects are due to the specific intervention or simply a placebo effect. This design helps ensure the validity and reliability of the study results.

Certainly. The experimental treatment involves the use of tumor treating fields (TTFields) through the NovoTTF-200T portable system. The system consists of a generator and the transducer arrays that deliver the TTFields. The generator is worn outside the body, providing a low-intensity, intermediate frequency (150-200 kHz) electric field to the tumor site. The transducer arrays, which are placed on the skin with the assistance of ultrasound guidance, generate the electric field, which is delivered directly to the tumor. The electrical current in the field is thought to alter the microtubule formation within the tumor cells, leading to a reduction in their reproductive capacity and ultimate necrosis of the cells.

Abstract:
The investigator has agreed that an independent pharmacovigilance committee will evaluate the safety and potential risk‐ benefit profile in clinical studies with Nesina/Nesina/Osenic. Data will be monitored according to predetermined criteria. The committee will evaluate all non‐routine, unexpected adverse events (AEs) and suspected adverse reactions that potentially relate to Nesina and its excipients, for which AEs or suspected adverse reactions occur in more than 10% of study patients, or in patients under 18 years of age (all dose levels), or in the event of a serious AE that potentially relates to Nesina, or that is serious in and of special interest to the pediatric population. Further, the committee will evaluate significant changes in ECG parameters, vital signs, physical examination, and clinical laboratory tests in clinical studies that occur in >10% of study patients (all dose levels), or in patients under 18 years of age, or in the event of serious AE that potentially relates to Nesina. The committee will evaluate potential changes in ECG parameters, vital signs, physical examination, and clinical laboratory tests in clinical studies in the pediatric population. In clinical studies in which new safety information emerges, the committee will assess and review the data in a timely manner and recommend appropriate modification(s) of the study. Clinical study reports will be presented to the committee for each clinical study in which new safety information emerges or the number of study patients who experience an AE or suspected adverse reaction increases significantly. The committee will review each clinical study report and will make recommendations with respect to Nesina and its excipients, based on a balanced interpretation of the new information, the characteristics of the clinical study, and a review of the relevant literature. The committee may also discuss relevant information on relevant marketed products. The committee will not consider any administrative, scientific, or legal aspects other than safety. In the event that the medical reviewers have serious reservations about the safety profile of Nesina, the committee will formulate recommendations to the Sponsor regarding the continued progress of the clinical study. The committee will forward its findings and recommendations to the Sponsor in writing.

Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is an acute and life-threatening syndrome that is triggered by the recipient’s immunologic reaction to foreign proteins expressed on donor erythrocytes. Donor specific anti-Human Leukocyte Antigen (HLA) antibodies (DSA) are a known risk factor for TRALI and transfusion-related acute lung injury, leading to reduced patient outcomes. This is problematic since in Europe and especially Italy, there is still a high rate of incompatibility at the ABO group. A study conducted in the 1990s showed that using A-A blood in ABO compatible transplants decreased the risk of TRALI and TRALI-associated complications at 15 days. It also enhanced survival at 15 days. In addition to lowering the risk of TRALI, the use of A-A blood is more cost-effective in the context of transplantation. During the first 8 weeks of treatment, a treatment plan will be established according to the therapeutic regimen of neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. The following 16 weeks will be treated based on the standard treatment regimen for advanced NSCLC patients. The primary endpoints of this study are the safety of the vaccine and chemotherapy in terms of the incidence and severity of adverse events (AEs). The secondary endpoints are the efficacy of the vaccine in terms of progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS). Secondary outcome

The secondary endpoint of the study includes the following:

2. Humoral immunity (anti-SARS-CoV-2 antibody levels) assessed after a D2 vaccination.

Abstract:
Background: Early detection of pancreatic cancer (PC) offers a chance for curative treatment. In resectable PC, laparoscopic distal pancreatectomy (LDP) has been shown to be safe and feasible. However, LDP may not be suitable for some patients. Laparoscopic radical antegrade modular pancreatosplenectomy (LRAMPS) is a less invasive technique for resection of early‐stage left‐sided PC, which is a potentially curable approach to patients with pancreatic head and uncinate tumors and those who are candidates for central pancreatectomy. However, few studies have investigated LRAMPS for early‐stage left‐sided PC. The aim of our study was to compare the perioperative outcomes of LRAMPS and LDP in patients with early‐stage left‐sided PC. Methods: This study is a single‐center, prospective, comparative study including patients with early‐stage left‐sided PC who underwent LRAMPS or LDP from November 2018 to May 2022. The primary outcomes were conversion to open surgery and surgical complications. The secondary outcomes included operation time, operating cost, length of hospital stay, intraoperative blood loss, pathological tumor size, and tumor staging. Results: 21 patients were excluded because they declined or failed to participate, whereas 86 patients were included (49 males, 37 females; Median age 60 years, range 34‐85 years). 43 patients underwent LRAMPS and 43 patients underwent LDP. The characteristics and perioperative outcomes of the two groups were compared. No significant differences were found between the two groups in terms of age, sex, body mass index, operation time, intraoperative blood loss, conversion to open surgery, pathological tumor size, tumor staging, or surgical complications. However, there was a significant difference in operating costs between the two groups (P=0.015). Conclusions: This study provides preliminary data on the feasibility and safety of LRAMPS for early‐s age left‐sided PC and compares perioperative outcomes with LDP. Our results suggest that L

Study Arm 1:
Participant Group/Arm: LRAMPS group
Intervention/Treatment: Procedure: LRAMPS
Patients who meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria will undergo laparoscopic radical antegrade modular pancreatosplenectomy (LRAMPS) surgery. This arm is necessary to compare the outcomes of patients undergoing LRAMPS with those undergoing LDP. The LRAMPS procedure involves the removal of Gerota's fascia and perirenal fat capsule, with the option to perform anterior or posterior LRAMPS depending on the resection of the left adrenal gland. The removal of specific lymph nodes is also outlined based on the tumor location.

Study Arm 2:
Participant Group/Arm: LDP group
Intervention/Treatment: Procedure: LDP
Patients who meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria will undergo laparoscopic distal pancreatosplecnectomy (LDP) surgery. This arm is essential to compare the outcomes of patients undergoing LDP with those undergoing LRAMPS. The LDP procedure involves dissection behind the fusion fascia and the removal of specific lymph nodes based on the tumor location. This arm allows for a comparison of outcomes between LDP and LRAMPS in the context of early-stage left-sided pancreatic cancer.
